full_text: Succeed Insurance requires that no reserves or payments can be made against claim cost when a claim is under SIU investigation. Such a claim should be put under financial hold. The first thing to do is to set up the cause for the financial hold. I navigate to the financial hold's enhancement. In the apply financial hold's function, I add a condition to the OR clause. The condition tests whether the claim is under SIU investigation. To save time, I have already added a condition to the OR clause. The condition tests whether the claim is under SIU investigation. I already created the rule I need. In the base configuration, there is a group of transaction set validation rules that deals with financial holds. The parent rule fires if the claim has a financial hold on it, as long as the transaction set type is reserve set or check set, and there are no deleted or cancelled checks. There are child rules that deal with the possible causes of financial holds. In the base configuration, there are three. Claims where coverage is in question. Incident only claims. And claims with unverified policies. I have placed my new rule under those three. The condition activates the rule only if the claim is under SIU investigation. The rule rejects the transaction set with an error if it has any component for claim cost. Otherwise, it rejects the transaction set with a warning. To test the rule I restart the server in debug mode. When the server is ready, I switch to Claim Center in the browser. And I log in as Sue Smith, a claims manager who has the right to set SIU status. Now I navigate to a claim. I look at the status screen. Where I see that the SIU status field for this claim is null. I'll change that. I navigate to the Special Investigation Details screen. Here, I click Edit. I refer the claim to the SIU team. In the Supervisor comment field that appears I indicate that this is a test. Now I save the changes I've made. Returning to the status screen. I verify that the SIU status is set. Now I'll try to create a reserve on the claim. Note that there are already several claim cost reserves on the claim. The new reserve is set to Claim Level from the start, so I'll set the cost type to Claim Cost. For Cost Category I'll simply select Other. And I'll set the amount to $5,000. Now I'll attempt to save the claim. As expected, the error message appears. If I attempt to save in this errored condition, nothing happens. I'll clear the error message. And change the cost type. Now, when I attempt to save. I see the warning message. I'll clear the message. Now when I click Save. The reserve is saved, with the status of Submitting. The rule is working correctly. This concludes the Configuring Financial Holds demonstration. .

segments.text: Succeed Insurance requires that no reserves or payments can be made against claim cost when a claim is under SIU investigation. Such a claim should be put under financial hold. The first thing to do is to set up the cause for the financial hold. I navigate to the financial hold's enhancement.
In the apply financial hold's function, I add a condition to the OR clause. The condition tests whether the claim is under SIU investigation.
To save time, I have already added a condition to the OR clause. The condition tests whether the claim is under SIU investigation.
I already created the rule I need.

In the base configuration, there is a group of transaction set validation rules that deals with financial holds. The parent rule fires if the claim has a financial hold on it, as long as the transaction set type is reserve set or check set, and there are no deleted or cancelled checks.
There are child rules that deal with the possible causes of financial holds. In the base configuration, there are three.

Claims where coverage is in question. Incident only claims. And claims with unverified policies. I have placed my new rule under those three. The condition activates the rule only if the claim is under SIU investigation.

The rule rejects the transaction set with an error if it has any component for claim cost. Otherwise, it rejects the transaction set with a warning. To test the rule I restart the server in debug mode.
When the server is ready, I switch to Claim Center in the browser. And I log in as Sue Smith, a claims manager who has the right to set SIU status.
Now I navigate to a claim. I look at the status screen. Where I see that the SIU status field for this claim is null. I'll change that. I navigate to the Special Investigation Details screen.
Here, I click Edit. I refer the claim to the SIU team. In the Supervisor comment field that appears I indicate that this is a test. Now I save the changes I've made.
Returning to the status screen. I verify that the SIU status is set. Now I'll try to create a reserve on the claim.
Note that there are already several claim cost reserves on the claim. The new reserve is set to Claim Level from the start, so I'll set the cost type to Claim Cost.
For Cost Category I'll simply select Other.
And I'll set the amount to $5,000.
Now I'll attempt to save the claim.
As expected, the error message appears. If I attempt to save in this errored condition, nothing happens.
I'll clear the error message.
And change the cost type.
Now, when I attempt to save.
I see the warning message. I'll clear the message.
Now when I click Save.
The reserve is saved, with the status of Submitting. The rule is working correctly.
This concludes the Configuring Financial Holds demonstration.
